column6: The purpose of the Electronic Bearing Line is to:

column6: Which of the following statements about "true bearing" is correct?

column7: The bow of the vessel always points up.

column10: It increases receiver gain for real targets.

column7: Eliminate fluctuating targets such as sea return.

column6: What does the term ARPA/CAS refer to?
column7: The basic RADAR system in operation.

column6: The ARPA term CPA refers to:

column9: The combined detection and processing of targets.
column10: The closest point a ship or target will approach your own ship.

column6: The display power supply provides the following:
column7: +18 volts DC for the pulse forming network.

column9: 17kV DC for the CRT HV anode.

column6: In a display system power supply what is the purpose of the chopper?

column8: It interrupts the AC supply line at a varying rate depending on the load demands.

column9: Acts as the voltage regulator for the 5 volt DC supply.

column9: The HV supply for the CRT anode.

column6: The heading flash is a momentary intensification of the sweep line on the PPI presentation. Its function is to:

column7: The same as the lowest component of the analog frequency.
column8: Two times the highest component of the analog frequency.
column9: Greater than two times the highest component of the sampled frequency.
column10: The same as the highest component of the sampled frequency.

column10: Maximum at the left hand end.

column7: The longer the antenna the wider the horizontal beamwidth.

If the TR tube malfunctions:

column8: Paint it with nonconductive paint to prevent rust.

column8: Large circular rings near the center.

column6: Why is coaxial cable often used for S-band installations instead of a waveguide?
column7: Losses can be kept reasonable at S-band frequencies and the installation cost is lower.

column9: S-band waveguide flanges show too much leakage and are unsafe for use near personnel.

column6: RADAR interference to a communications receiver is eliminated by:

column9: To minimize reception of horizontally polarized returns.

column6: In a RADAR system, waveguides should be installed:

column10: As long as possible for system flexibility.

column6: What is the most important factor to consider in locating the antenna?

column6: Choose the most correct statement with respect to component damage from electrostatic discharge:

column8: ESD damage occurs primarily in active components which are easily identified and replaced.
column9: The technician will feel a small static shock and recognize that ESD damage has occurred to the circuit.
column10: ESD damage may cause immediate circuit failures, but may also cause failures much later at times when the RADAR set is critically needed.

column6: Before testing a RADAR transmitter, it would be a good idea to:
column7: Make sure no one is on the deck.

column9: Make sure there are no explosives or flammable cargo being loaded.
column10: Make sure the Coast Guard has been notified.

column6: While making repairs or adjustments to RADAR units:
column8: Discharge all high-voltage capacitors to ground.

column6: If a CRT is dropped:
column7: Most likely nothing will happen because they are built with durability in mind.
column8: It might go out of calibration.
column10: It might implode, causing damage to workers and equipment.

column8: The waveguide is detached from the antenna to prevent radiation.
column9: The magnetic field is present to prevent over-current damage or overheating from occurring in the magnetron.
column10: Only non-conductive tools and devices are used.
